text: Yeah, they have static overloading still, but it'll do the 'wrong' thing dynamically. It does look like a cool language. It's probably what I'd reach for first if I wanted to learn a static language capable of making small binaries.

text: :+1: for Nim and ArrayMancer. I feel like the default memory management makes for a more accessible system than Zig, but still not sure how I feel about the compile-to-C aspect (e.g. <https://github.com/mratsim/Arraymancer/issues/478>)

text: Yea python white space is pretty painful. Never heard of zig. I have a need for a programming language that has a little bit more FP baked into it, but still reaches out to some goodies like OpenGL and stuff without any headaches. Not trying to replace julia but basically fill in some gaps.

text: Being almost completely ignorant of these new languages, I see little difference between Nim, Zig, Crystal and many other new languages. Unlike Rust and Julia they don't seem to have a unique selling point. Aren't they just "C, but written in the 2010s"? Can they offer something that e.g. Rust can't?

text:
I didn't know about function pointers, I haven't spent much time in C. Thank you.

I think it just further cements that I should use Go for my project. It's popular enough to get help, easy to write, does the parallelism thing very nicely and allows for some FP.  Binarys are a couple of Mb, which is kinda stinky but - not prohibitive for scale out or microservices. Really appreciate everyone helping me get a handle on the 'language landscape'.

elements.text:

Binarys are a couple of Mb, which is kinda stinky but - not prohibitive for scale out or microservices. Really appreciate everyone helping me get a handle on the 'language landscape'.

text: <@UPUBAM63X> Yeah Go is pretty nice. I got Julia as my favorite language, but depending on what I need to do, Go may be the second choice. However I see much potential for Zig in the  future. It is harder to learn, and has some more rough edges. But in a lot of ways it feels more innovative and better designed for proper engineering than Go. If you want really small binaries, you can easily distribute to any architecture then Zig is much better than Go. I have seen people doing microcontroller stuff that really like Zig. Go binaries are often way too large for that. If you are interested in a sort of intro or rational for Zig: <https://medium.com/swlh/zig-the-introduction-dcd173a86975>

attachments.title: Zig the Introduction
attachments.text: Have problems wrapping your head around the Zig programming language? Here is a guide.

text: <@U011V2YN59N> Yeah that has been my issue with Nim as well. For a lot of the stuff you can do in Nim, I just think: "Isn't Julia just a nicer way to do this?" If I want to do high level application programming, can't I just use Swift or Rust instead of Nim? As you said it is hard to see the niche. Perhaps if you are a Python programmer and really love that syntax. I don't like that syntax, so I may not be in the target group.

elements.text: Yeah that has been my issue with Nim as well. For a lot of the stuff you can do in Nim, I just think: "Isn't Julia just a nicer way to do this?" If I want to do high level application programming, can't I just use Swift or Rust instead of Nim? As you said it is hard to see the niche. Perhaps if you are a Python programmer and really love that syntax. I don't like that syntax, so I may not be in the target group.

text: Thanks Erik it seems like we kind of see things the same way. Julia is my primary language and will continue to be for a long while(most of my work is computational). But, for deployment, I almost always need another option to satisfy stakeholders. Zig looks cool - I just get worried about some of these bleeding edge languages. Julia - which is remarkably stable for what it is has almost killed work projects for me. More so ecosystem related, but I've had 2 close calls so far, and I'm pretty far from an adrenaline junkie. So I am looking for something, a little mainstream for practical reasons (support, stability, longevity, etc).

elements.text: Thanks Erik it seems like we kind of see things the same way. Julia is my primary language and will continue to be for a long while(most of my work is computational). So I am looking for something, a little mainstream for practical reasons (support, stability, longevity, etc).

text: for researchers & students these languages are probably immaculate and super fun. But I live in a world were failure to deliver on time can mean joblessness with a bad review for future work. So I tend to tread a little carefully.

elements.text: for researchers & students these languages are probably immaculate and super fun. But I live in a world were failure to deliver on time can mean joblessness with a bad review for future work. So I tend to tread a little carefully.

text: Just use python like everybody else?

elements.text: Just use python like everybody else?

text: <@UPUBAM63X> If you need to play and safe and have super easy deployment, then I would definitely choose Go. It is a bit boring compared to Julia, but it has a lot of the same simplicity and straightforward manner of working. Even if Python is much more similar to Julia than Go, I find myself oddly preferring Go. The Python ecosystem just feels too complex to me. All these different virtual environments. Different REPLs, multitude of competing packages for the same thing. The whole Python 2 vs Python 3 mess.  Go is just so much more straight forward to do stuff with. Yes it is more verbose, but Go code is really easy to read and work with.

elements.text: If you need to play and safe and have super easy deployment, then I would definitely choose Go. Even if Python is much more similar to Julia than Go, I find myself oddly preferring Go. The Python ecosystem just feels too complex to me. All these different virtual environments. Different REPLs, multitude of competing packages for the same thing. The whole Python 2 vs Python 3 mess.  Go is just so much more straight forward to do stuff with. Yes it is more verbose, but Go code is really easy to read and work with.

text: btw Python 2 has been depreciated for almost a year already, my distro doesn't even have it packaged

text:
Yea I think Go hits a nice middle ground for me. It isn't like some glorious language, and I can see Rust has a technical edge. But I am with you it seems to be where I should be looking for this. Julia is so close - in a few years it'll be exactly what I need, but I can't wait years.

Oliver & Erik - Okay so I switched away from python EXCEPT when I need something and Julia is giving me a really hard time with it(pretty rare but it happens). My second day of actual work I almost called a py2 lib but instead spent a half hour writing my own version in Julia way faster/better. Why, not use python? Sometimes it makes me ill? Is that fair :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing: But yea, the python ecosystem is kind of a waste land.

text: <@UDSU53PEG> A lot of standard docker containers use Python 2. Last time I needed to something Gradle related with a docker image, I was forced to use Python 2, or I would have had to build by own docker image for Gradle, which I would not want to do.

text: oh that's so scary. Yea I know people are STILL doing dev in Py2. I tried my hardest at one job to get people to make the switch but they had too much code. Like a decade of scrapped together code written by hundreds of people coming and going(turn over rate was <1yr). To be fair - this was before that version was deprecated (and I celebrated).

text: hardest part of industry is - convincing people not to shoot themselves in the foot with tech. Python is very much alive and kicking. I either want speed and quick access to math, or I want static typing and less hooplah.

text: Very interesting with your ZMQ stuff. It has been something I also often wanted to explore to be able to write my GUI layer in whatever tools excels at that and use my favorite language (Julia) for the backend. I have toyed with the idea of using Godot game engine as a GUI layer and talk to Julia. Godot has just awesome GUI design tools, and very nice language for configuring a GUI.

text: So Go has some pretty awesome GUI options(from my quick survey). QT and stuff(also in Julia now via QML). But they have these other little niche libraries that look so nifty. ZMQ is cool - the proper thing is to directly access memory(IE pass pointers/call fns). But when it's too hairy(I felt it was for Java due to the JVM) ZMQ is a pretty okay abstraction.

elements.text: So Go has some pretty awesome GUI options(from my quick survey). QT and stuff(also in Julia now via QML). But they have these other little niche libraries that look so nifty. text: That's not what ZMQ is really made for, but it is easy to deal with. In some cases it's an easy abstraction to remote computing, in other's there's better tools :slightly_smiling_face:. Turns out someone made a Java interop lib for Julia since that post(never tried it but sounds cool!)

text: <@UDSU53PEG> there where official docker images. I don't think it is my job as a casual user of them to be updating them. I just had a short job to get done. Creating some docker image with Python 3 would have been far much more work than I was interested in doing. Just underscoring my issue with Python. Too much mess to deal with, that I don't have time for. If Python was my bread and butter, then sure.... but I prefer to only use it when Julia is not an option.

text: <https://github.com/rust-windowing/winit>

Rust is cool Oliver, there's promising libs there too. But the structures I need to build this thing would be a ton of pain points that a solodev probably couldn't overcome unless they had other motivations(money, or need to graduate). I have neither of those, and don't want to fall into the trap that some of the dead libs in Rust already has :(. GUI is just a side need of a larger project. Go removes a ton of those issues, despite being limited with generics.

text: I'm not against Mac! I just never had the $$$ for them(new job means next time I am on the market for a computer I can though!). They seem like great devices - we love our Ipad.

text: Actually I had some rather geeky reasons for why I became a Mac user. I used to make fun of Macs for having a single mouse button, but I used to read these old computer magazines about NeXSTEP and as a Unix fan it got me mesmerized. Smalltalk was one of the first languages which really blew me away. So the fact that NeXT gave taste of that through Objective-C got me really interested in NeXT early. When I heard Apple was basing Mac OS X on NeXT I was totally sold. I had to get a Mac!

elements.text: Actually I had some rather geeky reasons for why I became a Mac user. I used to make fun of Macs for having a single mouse button, but I used to read these old computer magazines about NeXSTEP and as a Unix fan it got me mesmerized. Smalltalk was one of the first languages which really blew me away. So the fact that NeXT gave taste of that through Objective-C got me really interested in NeXT early. When I heard Apple was basing Mac OS X on NeXT I was totally sold. I had to get a Mac!

text: My first Mac was the G4 Cube, and the experience of powering that thing on for the first time, was so out of this world compared to anything I had experienced on the PC thus far. It was like having gotten access to some alien technology. I was totally sold. Macs today don't give that same relative difference in feeling. But back then the gap was really big.

text: Yeah they may get the performance advantage, but back then it was easier to differentiate because PCs back then were really big ugly and noisy machines. The G4 Cube was a like a beautiful piece of art and completely silent due to cooling through convection through a central shaft. And Apple used this fancy touch system where it was like the whole thing was encased in transparent plastic. When you touched the power button, the interior of the transparent plastic under your finger lit up.... sure nobody "needs" that, but it was just so super duper cool.
